text: the following report contains some
disturbing images in three horrific
years in Syria
no single incident has been worse than
the chemical attack that killed and
injured so many people in the rebel-held
suburbs of Damascus a year ago the West
and the rebels blamed the Assad regime
it denied the charge the Americans had
threatened trouble unspecified if mass
casualties were inflicted by chemical
weapons when all these people were
killed US military action against the
Assad regime looked certain in Damascus
at that time supporters of President
Assad were volunteering for militias
amid real anxiety about what the
Americans might do the war seemed to be
at a turning point in Britain Parliament
was recalled and voted against joining
the Americans in bombing Syria it was a
big factor in America's decision to
cancel the airstrikes at the last minute
I think the policy that the American
government followed on Syria even before
the chemical attacks was tentative and
indecisive and I think it sent a signal
to people in both the moderate rebels in
Syria but particularly to the extreme
rebels in Syria that we were not
prepared to reengage in this region for
President Assad supporters volunteering
as human shields at potential targets in
Damascus the deal looked good Syria
would give up its chemical Arsenal to
lift the threat of an American attack
the Assad regime recovered its nerved it
believed the Americans had blinked first
history is full of what-ifs a major
reason why there's been no direct
Western military intervention in the
Syrian war has been fear of the
consequences not just getting sucked
into a political and military morass but
actively making matters worse not better
but what if the Americans had bombed
Assad's men it would not have ended the
war but it might have changed the
balance of power it could have been the
catalyst for more American support for
Syrian insurgents who were also opposed
to the jihadist group that was then
called Isis that's certainly what Syrian
fighters who were hoping for more
Western support believe by Lowell manam
done mobile if American strikes had
happened the regime wouldn't have been
strengthened Islamic state wouldn't have
been strengthened because the airstrikes
didn't happen the FSA is now having
defied the regime and Islamic state the
conflict in Syria has evolved into a
series of overlapping civil wars you can
see it in a letter where I was earlier
this summer the Syrian government fights
insurgents sometimes the insurgents also
fight each other
Isis now rebranded as Islamic state came
into Syria from Iraq as an al Qaeda
offshoot it has fought the anti regime
forces more than its fought the Syrian
regime itself
the rise of Isis in Syria gave it a
launchpad to storm back into Iraq it's
captured large amounts of American
weaponry from the Iraqi armed
Iraqi security forces were strengthening
their positions on the edge of Baghdad
in July against the Islamic state
advance I asked has exploited the anger
of Arab Sunnis furious at the way Iraqi
shears have monopolized power but now
there's a new government in Baghdad
Iraq's best hope is that it will offer
Sunnis enough to turn them away from is
that won't happen easily then no IRG
himoto may be - oh we will not fight
Isis or any other terrorism as long as
we haven't received our right and we
will not fight terrorism or what is
known as Isis as long as the government
has not stood up to terrorists Shia
militias which butchers Sunnis the West
is deeply involved in this crisis even
though it would prefer to stay out
Britten's deliveries of humanitarian aid
could turn into a deeper military role
perhaps directed at the several thousand
British and other European men who fight
for is in Damascus this morning families
displaced by three years of fighting
were going home after a local truce in
their suburb between the regime and
rebels as the Syrian regime comes its
capital its hoping for at least a tacit
alliance with the US Britain and France
against Islamic state that would be a
remarkable turnaround for President
Assad who may already be the leader
who's done best out of the last year
Jeremy Bowen BBC News
